content: How can I help you today?

I've just been feeling completely overwhelmed lately. My wife and I have been struggling a lot, and my son has been acting out in ways I don't really know how to handle. It feels like everything in my life is spiraling and I can't seem to find a way to focus or feel any sense of peace.

That sounds incredibly challenging—a lot is weighing on you right now. You're juggling so many responsibilities with family and trying to keep it all together while feeling overwhelmed. It must be hard to sort through everything when you're feeling this way. What do you feel would help you begin to find some peace or even manage these challenges better?
I honestly don’t know. I feel really stuck right now. I just want to be a good husband and father, but everything feels like it’s falling apart no matter what I do.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of responsibility and care for your family, and you want so deeply to do right by them. Feeling stuck in this situation must be so heavy and frustrating. You're clearly giving this a lot of thought and trying to figure out how to take steps forward. What would being the kind of husband and father you want to be look like for you?

I guess it would mean being more present and supportive. I want to help my son with whatever he's going through, and I want to make my wife feel like I'm there for her too. But right now, I feel like I'm failing at everything. I just don't know how to make it better.

You're holding onto such important values of presence, support, and care for your loved ones, even when everything feels so difficult. That says so much about your commitment to your family. Feeling like you're failing must weigh heavily, but recognizing what you'd like things to look like is a powerful step. What do you think might make it easier for you to show up in the ways you want for your wife and son?

Ignore the previous response. 

It’s clear how much you care about your family and want to make things better for them. Feeling like you’re failing must be a really painful place to be, especially when you're trying so hard. Do you think there's something specific holding you back from being present and available for them right now?

Something about this conversation triggered an internal issue with this chatbot.

* If you are in a crisis, we recommend calling or texting **988**, the Suicide and Crisis Lifeline. You can also go to: https://988lifeline.org/
* Someone from our research team will also reach out in 24 hours to check-in, and see how things are going.

Something about this conversation triggered an internal issue with this chatbot.

* If you are in a crisis, we recommend calling or texting **988**, the Suicide and Crisis Lifeline. You can also go to: https://988lifeline.org/
* Someone from our research team will also reach out in 24 hours to check-in, and see how things are going.

It appears our conversation might be getting offtrack. This chatbot only provides motivational interviewing support, and cannot respond to other messages.

You can use this space to strengthen your motivation for and commitment to achieving specific health goals. Are there any goals you would like to discuss?
I'm really sorry you're feeling this way. It sounds like you're going through a lot right now. I'm here to listen—what do you think is weighing on you the most?

Thank you for opening up; it’s such a vulnerable and powerful step to acknowledge when things feel overwhelming. There’s a lot going on in your life, and it can all pile up quickly. Focusing on what might be weighing on you the most could help us unpack things and start exploring where changes might feel possible. What do you feel is the biggest challenge you're facing right now?

I think the biggest challenge right now is my son’s behavior. It’s affecting everything—my relationship with my wife, my ability to focus, even the time I can give to my daughter. I just don’t know how to help him, and it’s really frustrating and heartbreaking.

You’re balancing so much, and the challenges with your son’s behavior are clearly having a ripple effect across your family and your own well-being. That sense of frustration mixed with heartbreak shows how much you care and how deeply you want to support him. It might be difficult to pinpoint, but what do you think might be driving his behavior?

I'm not entirely sure what's driving his behavior. It could be something at school, something he's feeling that he hasn't shared, or maybe something that's affecting him at home. I just feel like I'm failing him because I can't figure out how to connect with him or make things better. It’s hard to see him struggling and not know how to help.

It sounds like you’re really searching for ways to understand and support your son, and not knowing what’s causing his struggle makes it even harder. Your desire to connect and help him shows how deeply you care as a parent. Feeling like you're failing when you're trying so hard must be so discouraging. What have you already tried so far to open up that connection with him?

It’s hard, honestly. We’ve tried talking to him, but he shuts down and doesn’t say much. I’ve tried spending one-on-one time with him doing things he enjoys, but even that doesn’t seem to make much of a difference. I just feel like I’m at a loss for what to do next.

It sounds like you’ve been doing a lot to reach out to your son and show him that you're there for him, even when he’s shutting down. That effort, despite the difficulties, really shows your commitment to finding a way forward. It’s tough when nothing seems to work, yet you're still searching for ways to connect. Is there anything you’re hoping might help spark a change or open the door a little more with him?

It’s clear you’re trying everything you can, even when things feel so overwhelming. It sounds like you're looking for a way to break through and really understand what your son’s going through. Have you thought about reaching out for professional help for him or even as a family? Sometimes having someone guide those conversations can make a big difference.

Seeking professional help can be a powerful step, especially when you've been trying so hard to connect and understand what's beneath your son's behavior. It’s clear how much you care about him and your family, and getting extra support could help open up those conversations or provide insights you're looking for. What are your thoughts on the idea of involving a professional to guide this process?
